item.title: Stop with coding exams
item.dc:creator: Johnny Breen
item.description:
You may be wondering what the point of this blog post is. Well, I‚Äôve been bottling this frustration up for years now.

I want to start by telling you a little (intentionally vague) story about me: I didn‚Äôt start out as a ‚Äòdata scientist‚Äô (I‚Äôm still not, technically, a ‚Äòdata scientist‚Äô but hey-ho). I started out training to be.. a professional of a certain caliber, in the insurance industry, as part of an organisation that shan‚Äôt be named.. üôÑ

Excuse these vagaries: those who know me will know what I am talking about; uttering the name of that organisation (they shall be known as ‚ÄòThe Organisation‚Äô henceforth) in a public blog post is apparently tantamount to exclaiming the words ‚ÄòVoldemort‚Äô in Hogwarts. Anyway, I digress.

As part of my membership of this organisation I had to partake in exams, some of which required us to write code using R. Me being the R hobbyist that I always have been, I interpreted this move as a good one initially. Isn‚Äôt it great that the use of R is being expanded in the insurance industry?

Well it would be if it was done right. Unfortunately, the execution has been less than impressive.

You see, there‚Äôs the right way to do this and the wrong way to do this. Then there‚Äôs the really wrong way to do this, which is unfortunately the route ‚Äòthey‚Äô went down when they wrote this syllabus.

They decided: ‚ÄúYou know what, we‚Äôll ask them to write answers using code.. in a word document because god forbid you start using R Markdown for its intended purpose!‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, while you‚Äôre at it, why don‚Äôt you also examine them on how many function names they can remember from standard libraries (because you don‚Äôt do third-party packages, do you..). That way, they‚Äôre sure to improve their programming skills, right?‚Äù

OK, I am being facetious but you get the idea! No, this is clearly the wrong way to go about all of this and I am truly saddened to say this because I really believed that this could work. Truly. But it hasn‚Äôt and now a generation of analysts are suffering as a result.

Why this is a problem

You see, when I first learnt how to write code, I didn‚Äôt really learn how to write code.

I learnt how to solve a problem using code as a tool. This was good to some degree - there‚Äôs a lot of satisfaction in solving a problem using code. But it was also bad for reasons I would not have been able to perceive at the time.

See, there‚Äôs an astronomical difference between writing code for yourself, and writing code for other people (including your future self). In industry, we often do the latter not the former which means that code quality and organisation is paramount.

But if you‚Äôre sitting a timed exam where ‚Äògetting the answer‚Äô is the most important goal then you have absolutely no incentive to improve your code quality. What are we doing to our industry by teaching these heuristics to a whole generation of analysts? Nothing good, that‚Äôs for sure.

You think you‚Äôre learning how to write good programs; but what you‚Äôre actually doing is assembling sushi with a sledgehammer.

The Organisation claim that it would be prohibitive to allow analysts more time to complete their answers or, god forbid, submit a hard-fought personal project instead. There are concerns that this would compromise standards, ‚Äòhigh standards‚Äô they have maintained for almost a century.

I‚Äôm actually a fan of the coursework approach. I‚Äôm also a fan of not grading the coursework either; just require candidates to do their best and come up with an interesting angle on an appropriate schema of data using R or Python and issue a simple ‚ÄòPass‚Äô or ‚ÄòFail‚Äô. I can guarantee that whilst this approach may be more effort to mark (ahem, pay your markers a fair wage please), candidates will come away with a much greater understanding of how to write code than they ever would have via an examination format.

I can already hear the retort though: : ‚ÄúWell, we can‚Äôt let them submit their own coursework.. what about plagiarism?‚Äù

My response to this is, well, what about it? You‚Äôre supposed to be teaching people how to be better software developers; you‚Äôre not just here to maintain absolute standards. If 5% of candidates commit plagiarism, you can be sure they haven‚Äôt learnt anything. It‚Äôs their loss and you should accept that these anomalies may slip through the cracks.

The other 95% however? They will benefit immensely from a chance to implement their skills in a personal project, regardless of what grade they are given - certainly far more than having to sit through a dull litany of R commands and reciting them to the RStudio console when the exam comes around.

item.title: Closures
item.dc:creator: Johnny Breen
item.description:
Another day goes by and another poor sod finds themselves trawling through Google to figure out what on earth a closure is.

Well, I say that as if this is some kind of ‚Äòhot‚Äô topic in the #rstats community: it‚Äôs not. If anything it‚Äôs ‚Äòhot‚Äô for all the wrong reasons: we‚Äôve all come across the error ‚Äòobject of type closure is not subsettable‚Äô before.

You can be a very capable data scientist and have no clue what a closure is. But, I actually like this stuff. Plus, this concept is something that is shared amongst other popular programming languages like JavaScript, Swift and Ruby so it‚Äôs kind of useful to know what it is.

So, presuming you‚Äôre not bored yet and still wondering what I‚Äôm on about, have a little look at the following code snippet and have a little think about what would happen if I called g. Try to think about it yourself before scrolling further!

# Returns another function which has the ability to print the value for the symbol `text`
f <- function() {
  
  text <- "Here!"
  
  function() {
    print(text)
  }
}

# Returns a call to the function returned by `f()` (above)
g <- function() {
  
  text <- "There!"
  
  print_text <- f()
  print_text()
}

Have you thought about it yet?

Good. OK: here goes nothing!

g()
[1] "Here!"

Boom. Now, if you aren‚Äôt a regular user of R this behaviour could be quite bemusing. For instance, we have defined two values for the symbol text: how does R select one of them?

Even if you are a regular user of R, you may still be wondering how to explain this. And you wouldn‚Äôt really be able to without first understanding the concept of closures and lexical scope. So let me attempt to elucidate things for you slightly :wink:

A simple example

The example shown above is a little bit complicated.

So let‚Äôs start with something really simple and build up the complexity as we go. First, take a look at this function

open <- function() {
  x + 3
}

You‚Äôll see why I‚Äôve called it ‚Äòopen‚Äô in a minute.

Most users of R understand that if we tried to run open, as is, we would face an error because we haven‚Äôt yet defined a value for x within the function body or within the global environment.

Let‚Äôs verify that with a quick call,

open()
Error in open(): object 'x' not found

This of course changes once we assign a value to the symbol x, say, within the global environment,

x <- 2

open()
[1] 5

The question is: how does open locate a value for the symbol x? I mean, we haven‚Äôt defined it inside the function body so how does open ‚Äòjump up‚Äô into the global environment whilst it is executing?

Expressions & closures

Take a look at the following function closed,

closed <- function(x, y) {
  x + y
}

This function is a closed expression because each and every symbol that is defined inside the body of g has a corresponding value (supplied as arguments to the parameters x and y).

By contrast, the aforementioned function open is an open expression,

open <- function() {
  x + 3
}

This is because the symbol x is not defined anywhere within the function itself. We call x a free variable in this context. It needs a value; it needs closure.

When we created open, we assigned it to the global environment,

rlang::env_has(env = .GlobalEnv, nms = "open")
open 
TRUE

When you define a function inside a given context (say, the global environment, as we just did), that function will assign and maintain values associated with all of the free variables of that function expression which exist within the surrounding context (and the context surrounding that context and so on, recursively).

Phew. That‚Äôs a lot of words! Let‚Äôs look at an example to make this a little easier to understand.

For example,

t <- 1
u <- 2
v <- 3
x <- 10

open <- function() {
  x + 3
}

In this case, the surrounding environment of open is as follows:

# Surrounding context of 'open'
{
  t: 1,
  u: 2,
  v: 3,
  x: 10
}

The closure of open is a subset of this environment: it is the set of key-value pairs which transform open from an open expression into a closed expression. In this case, we only care about x,

# Closure of 'open'
{
  x: 10
}

This is what a closure is!

Inner functions

Let‚Äôs go back to our initial problem.

We have a function f that is defined like so,

# Returns another function which has the ability to print the value for the symbol `text`
f <- function() {
  
  text <- "Here!"
  
  function() {
    print(text)
  }
}

Notice that f returns a function as an output.

I‚Äôm going to assign a name to this inner function to make things a bit easier to explain,

# Returns another function which has the ability to print the value for the symbol `text`
f <- function() {
  
  text <- "Here!"
  
  inner <- function() {
    print(text)
  }
  
  return(inner)
}

The important thing to note here, once again, is that the inner function is not executed, but is instead defined when f is called. So think of ‚Äòcall f‚Äô and ‚Äòdefine inner‚Äô as being equivalent statements.

When you run f(), here‚Äôs what happens.

First, you create another function (which I have just named print_text),

print_text <- f()

print_text
function() {
    print(text)
  }
<environment: 0x12004e7b8>

However, something else also happens behind the scenes which you don‚Äôt see: upon definition, the inner function creates a snapshot of the free variables (i.e. text) in its surrounding context,

{
  text: "Here!"
}

In effect, the inner function ‚Äòencloses‚Äô its surrounding context.

This is the closure of inner and this is how inner gets a value for text. This value is maintained even after f finishes executing.

Lexical scope versus dynamic scope

The concept of closures is closely related to the concept of lexical scope.

Let‚Äôs do a full reprise and bring g back into the equation,

f <- function() {
  
  text <- "Here!"
  
  inner <- function() {
    print(text)
  }
  
  return(inner)
}

g <- function() {
  
  text <- "There!"
  
  print_text <- f()
  print_text()
}

We now know that when we call f - and create inner - a closure is created for the inner function which allows it to lookup the value of text, ‚ÄúHere!‚Äù, when it is invoked.

In other words, the inner function binds values to its ‚Äòfree‚Äô symbols according to where it is defined in the source code itself (this is lexical scoping). It does not, by contrast, bind its values based on how it is called (this is dynamic scoping).

The word ‚Äòlexical‚Äô is used because it is indicative of text or source code. The word ‚Äòdynamic‚Äô is used because it is indicative of a ‚Äòruntime‚Äô definition.

To relate this to the example above,

g() # lexical scope - R does this
[1] "Here!"
g() # dynamic scope - R does not do this
[1] "There!"

The latter would be an implementation of dynamic scope because, if the variable text were scoped at runtime rather than where it was defined in the source code, it would simply look at the call stack (rather than the ‚Äòdefinition stack‚Äô if that‚Äôs even a word) and see text <- "There!".

Why is this cool?

OK, so why does this even matter as a concept? Well, for one you now understanding something better than you did before: is the intrinsic joy of learning not enough for you?

If you‚Äôre looking for a cool application, run over to this chapter of Hadley Wickham‚Äôs book Advanced R to see how you can create a function which counts how many times it has been called!
